comment info: I notice that women consist of more than half of essential workers by 2%, granted that is not a huge gap but it is huge in this male dominated world. name: Joseph Mezgebe
comment info: After analyzing the graph, I notice that the majority of essential workers are women, with a 52% share. Essential occupations such as resource extraction, farmers, and law enforcement have a majority of men, which may stem from previous social beliefs about occupations for women. One statistic that surprises me is the health care and social care share, which display a majority of women in that field. Even through acts of oppression throughout the 20th century, women are able to receive the majority of essential jobs in our nation, but this doesn’t coordinate with another statistic. Although women take the majority of essential occupations, does their compensation coordinate with their importance in these occupations? Due to previous acts of oppression, it has been an ongoing issue that is still debated. Regardless of the reasoning, women have and will remain an important aspect of the American workforce.

name: Wyatt Flewelling
comment info: To be honest, I wasn't surprised with the graph. It makes sense that a little more than half of all essential workers are female because that is obviously how the world is made up. Beyond that, it will be interesting to see if or how this demographic changes in the next few years. Overall, it is great to see how many women have essential jobs in the U.S. after overcoming oppression from the past and still to this day.

name: Ava Laska
comment info: In this graph I notice that the medical field and social sciences are more dominated by women, while the law enforcement careers are stereotypically masculine jobs. I wonder what started these stereotypes that women are expected to work in the medical field. I believe that having this stereotype predetermines what career young girls choose to have in the future because they think it is their only option. If there was more representation in stereotypically manly jobs, then young girls would see they can also choose to do that when they’re older. Also, the women in the medical field are risking their lives every day because of COVID, so to say that women are weak or need a mans protection is extremely sexist.

name: Paige L.
comment info: I think this graph is very interesting, and frankly, almost exactly what I would have predicted it to look like. The gender stereotypes I have grown up with and been exposed to are apparent even in the occupational differences between women and men. The medical field and social sciences have always seemed more feminine to me, rather than law enforcement and defense, which appear more predominantly male. I believe a good question to ask ourselves, though, is if this separation of genders in the workplace is inherently bad. Personally, I would argue that no, these differences are not harmful to either gender. They can become detrimental, though, when certain stigmas or stereotypes are enforced because of mere statistics. For example, to say that women only belong in the health fields because they are not capable of anything else, is not only wrong, but also extremely limiting to young girls as they consider their futures. I think that each person should be challenging themselves to think outside of the societal norms that have been in place for decades, encouraging the breakdown of these barriers. No woman, or man, should feel inferior or superior to another simply because of their occupation. I believe it is time to begin challenging the status quo of women in the workforce, encouraging this nation’s young girls to explore their true desires, not those that have been predetermined for them.

name: Kirk Hammer
comment info:
1. I notice that the jobs that are predominantly held by women tend to be occupations in which one is taking care of another. For example, women take up 77% of health care jobs and 78% of social worker jobs. 

2. I wonder why my previous response is applicable to the world today. I wonder why the percentage of women to men in every job is not near 50%. There are several arguments for why this happens and I will not elaborate on them, but I do feel that the opportunities for both genders should be more equal than they are today. Although your job is technically a choice, I feel as if the choices are limited for women and they are almost forced to go into--for lack of a better term--caring jobs.

3. I decided to name this graph "The Importance of the World's Women in Essential Roles" because I personally believe that the world would be much worse if not for the women in today's "essential occupations."

comment info:

name: Alejandra A.
comment info: This graph of the week presents the percentage of essential workers that are female as well as the breakdown of that percentage in each occupation. Based off of the information provided by the graph, I noticed that the majority of female essential workers operate in the areas of healthcare and social services. Moreover, women clearly make up slightly over half of essential workers as a whole. I find it encouraging, as a girl, that men and women are both roughly equal in the present-day realm of the workforce. The actual number of total female essential workers is astounding because 52% of the total 48,710,000 workers is 25,329,200. Nevertheless, returning to the initial detail that I noticed about the more common areas that female essential workers operate in, I wonder what most of their positions are in that area. For instance, in healthcare, are there more female doctors, nurses, or receptionists, among the other available jobs in that area. I wonder the same in the area of female social workers as well. These queries are simply out of curiosity, because a person’s role as an essential worker shouldn’t be undermined by their position or particular job. When it comes to my community in New Jersey, my mom is a NICU nurse and many of my friends’ and classmates’ mom or parent is a nurse. However, I personally don’t know any social workers. My catchy headline for this graph would be “Women are Essential”.

name: Rigel Velez
comment info:
I notice that there is a higher percentage of women working in white-collar jobs than in blue-collar jobs. Assuming that Social workers, Health care, Medical supplies, and Financial IT are all white-collar jobs and the rest are blue-collar and that the numbers in the middle were the percent of women in the job, then 75.59% of the 22,290,000 white-collar workers, are women. However, women only hold 31.09% of 26,500,000 blue-collar jobs. 

I also noticed that when you add up all of the total workers on the right side of the graph, they equal 48,790,000, as opposed to the 48,710,000 that are all the essential workers. I thought that maybe the percent of total essential workers that are women would be different, but after finding the amount of women for all of the individual types of jobs and then adding them up and dividing them by the total number of workers, I got 52% which was what the graph had originally said. 

I wonder where the extra 80,000 workers came from when adding the number of workers on the right. 
I wonder why there are more women in white-collar jobs than in blue-collar.
Lastly, I wonder how accurate these numbers are today, and how much they have changed from this 2014-2018 survey.

I think this graph could be called: "Are Essential jobs need Essential Woman."

name: Dylan Gasaway
comment info: One of the first things I noticed from this graph is that the majority of these essential jobs aren’t necessarily ones that pay the best. The jobs that stick out to me the most that represent this the most is social workers, retail, food processing, delivery, farmers, handling hazardous. This arises a question, why are the jobs that we find the most essential and important, not the jobs that pay the most to those who work them. Personally I believe it is this way for a number of reasons. For farmers it is this way in order to maintain an unreasonable price for food. For retail it is this way because major corporations have total control over their workers because they are easily replaced. All of these jobs have their own reasons that I could dive into; however, I won’t for the sake of brevity. To keep my response concise I would like to conclude it here by saying that it is unreasonable for these absolutely essential workers to be treaty so unfairly by major corporations in order to maintain a unreasonable status quo, and that these unforeseen times have brought this issue to light.

name: Moderator Gina
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  We had so many great catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graphs including “Women are Essential for Essential Jobs; You are our Superheroes!” by Arabella of New Hampshire, “Women: essential to overcoming this pandemic” by Sam of New Jersey, and “Women Dominate Essential Workers...or do they?" by Ruth of Maryland.

name: Sharon HESSNEY
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

At the beginning of the Covid-19 pandemic, the Department of Homeland Security designated which job categories were essential.  These workers should be going to their jobs.  Today’s graph shows the share of “essential workers” who are women.  

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and “What impact does this topic have on you and your community?”  Then, please share a catchy headline that captures the idea in the graph. 

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the article that included this graph and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.
Note that you can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”

name: Allison
comment info:
I find it interesting that it's so easy to draw two completely different conclusions from the data. You could argue that women are at a greater risk, since this data clearly shows that more women than men are essential workers. But you could also argue that the gender imbalance is surprisingly nonexistent, since women only make up 52% (as opposed to, say, 80%, which would be a far greater imbalance) of the essential workforce. It just struck me as interesting that it would be so easy to use this data to argue either way.

Catchy headline: "Essential Workers: Not As Male as We Thought"

Joke headline: "The Pandemic is Dangerous, but at Least It's Not Sexist" (This isn't a great headline because it could easily be misinterpreted as referring to infection rates, not essential workers. Which is why it's a joke headline. But it's still catchy.)

name: Alex
comment info:
I noticed that although out of the total number of essential workers women only take up 4% more than men, the data is extremely varied across all occupations, ranging from 11% in resource extraction to 78% of social workers. Personally, I was shocked when I also noticed that women constitute 77% of the healthcare workforce, which is nearly 40% of all essential occupations.
	I wonder why teaching and education have not been included in the essential works list, and if they were, what would the share of women in that area be? Would that data entry drive the average percentage of women in the essential workforce upwards? If yes, that (alongside their share in healthcare) would once again show us just how incredibly important women’s jobs really are and the degree to which our entire society relies on them.
	At the moment, this particular topic has a tremendous impact on the entire nation, including me and the community in which we live. In a time when the majority of the workforce is slowly just starting to come back to work, it is the essential workers who have been carrying all of us on their backs by working on the frontlines in spite of all the risks — the vast majority of them were women. Now, it is our responsibility to remember their effort and be thankful for their unconditional desire to help everyone else.
	Finally, a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea would be “Who are our frontline workers?”
